questions.question_text: In the last 6 to 12 months, what is one improvement that you have led in your school? This can be in students, teachers, parents or the school in general

response_fields.name: category_1
response_fields.description: Single category from: Classroom, Student, Teacher, School, Parental Engagement, Not Identified

response_fields.name: category_2
response_fields.description: Either LNF, Non-LNF or Not Identified

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY 1 DEFINITIONS (Choose ONE):

**Classroom**
Definition:
Use this when the improvement is about how teaching happens inside the classroom—methods, materials, routines, discipline, classroom setup, or subject-wise teaching.

Keywords:
TLM, teaching learning materials, activity-based learning, group work, pair work, charts, posters, learning walls, classroom beautification, seating arrangement changes, subject-specific improvement (math, reading, writing, science), reading corner, word wall, notebook maintenance, daily routines, new strategies from training, board work improvement, classroom management, lesson planning.

Examples:
- "I started using more TLMs and visual aids."
- "We arranged seating for group learning."
- "Created a reading corner for slow learners."
- "Started activity-based maths teaching."
- "Classroom environment is more organised now."

**Student**
Definition:
Use this when the improvement focuses on student outcomes — attendance, confidence, behaviour, learning levels, or motivation.

Keywords:
Attendance improved, learning levels increased, student confidence improved, regular homework, discipline improvement, curiosity increased, class participation, reading fluency, slow learners improved, ask more questions, behaviour improved, punctuality, teamwork, reduced fear of subjects.

Examples:
- "Students' attendance has improved."
- "Children are more confident now."
- "Slow learners can read sentences now."
- "Students participate more in class."
- "Homework completion has improved."

**Teacher**
Definition:
Use this when the improvement is about teacher development—collaboration, planning, motivation, professional practice.

Keywords:
Teacher collaboration, weekly teacher meetings, sharing practices, better lesson planning, teacher confidence improved, monitoring students better, self-learning, training, time management, teachers support each other, better record keeping, improved professional attitude.

Examples:
- "We started weekly teacher planning meetings."
- "I am more confident in managing the class."
- "Teachers collaborate and share strategies."
- "I learned to plan lessons after training."
- "Now I monitor student progress regularly."

**School**
Definition:
Use this when the improvement affects the whole school—systems, environment, infrastructure, culture, or shared spaces.

Keywords:
School cleanliness, campus beautification, school garden, kitchen garden, library improvement, positive school environment, morning assembly routine, school-wide discipline, waste management, notice boards, display boards, safe environment, school-wide attendance systems, common activity areas.

Examples:
- "We improved the school cleanliness."
- "Started a school kitchen garden."
- "Library is reorganised and used regularly."
- "Implemented morning assembly system."
- "School environment became more positive."

**Parental Engagement**
Definition:
Use this when the improvement is about parents' involvement, communication, relationship, or home-learning support.

Keywords:
PTM, parent-teacher meeting, parents visiting school, parents support homework, community involvement, awareness meetings, parents understand education value, parents monitor attendance, better teacher-parent communication, mothers' groups.

Examples:
- "We now conduct regular PTMs."
- "Parents support homework at home."
- "Communication with parents improved."
- "Parents participate in school activities."

**Not Identified**
Definition:
Use this category ONLY as a last resort. This is for responses that are too vague, do not describe a change, are non-answers, or are placeholder/error text.

Examples:
- "Nothing happened."
- "Same as before."
- "No improvement."
- "NA / N/A / --"
- Any unclear or philosophical statements.

---

CATEGORY 2 DEFINITIONS:

**LNF (Literacy Numeracy Fest)**
Definition:
Use the LNF category when the response explicitly or implicitly focuses on foundational literacy and/or numeracy improvements as the primary change or core focus. This includes efforts aimed at: improving reading, writing, comprehension; improving basic numeracy, counting, number sense; building daily or regular literacy/numeracy habits; implementing FLN-aligned classroom or school practices. The program name "Literacy Numeracy Fest" or "LNF" does NOT need to be explicitly mentioned. If the practice clearly aligns with foundational literacy or numeracy, classify it as LNF.

Keywords:
LNF, FLN, foundational literacy, foundational numeracy, literacy, numeracy, reading, reading corner, reading session, daily reading, library reading, phonics, reading aloud, reading fluency, comprehension, writing skills, handwriting improvement, counting, basic maths, number sense, numeracy activities, improving reading habits, improving literacy levels.

Examples:
- "I introduced daily reading sessions and a reading corner in my class which improved students' reading habits and confidence."
- "Students were weak in reading and counting earlier, but after focusing on foundational literacy and numeracy activities, they can now read and write better."
- "We started phonics and reading aloud activities to improve literacy among students."
- "Improvement in numeracy and literacy through regular practice and hands-on activities."
- "Children can now read fluently and understand basic maths concepts."

**Non-LNF**
Definition:
Use the Non-LNF category when the response does not primarily focus on literacy or numeracy learning outcomes, even if learning improves indirectly. This includes improvements mainly related to: parent-teacher meetings (PTM); school infrastructure or renovation; cleanliness, hygiene, sanitation; discipline, attendance, routines; mentorship, well-being, safety; community participation; co-curricular, cultural, sports activities; general teaching improvements without specific literacy or numeracy focus. If literacy or numeracy is not the central theme, classify as Non-LNF.

Examples:
- "Conducted regular PTMs to improve parent involvement in school activities."
- "Renovated classrooms and painted walls to make the school environment better."
- "Started morning assemblies and leadership roles like school captains."
- "Organised cleanliness drives with students and parents."
- "Introduced mentorship programs to improve student well-being and confidence."

**Not Identified**
Definition:
Use this category ONLY as a last resort. This is for responses that are too vague, do not describe a change, are non-answers, or are placeholder/error text.

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY DEFINITIONS (Can select MULTIPLE):

**System Directives & Program-Based Inspiration (LNF / EBRC / Govt-linked)**
Definition:
Use this category when the idea originated from formal, top-down, programmatic sources introduced by the education department or by external institutional programs. Includes ideas that explicitly reference Literacy Numeracy Fest (LNF / FLN Fest), EBRC guidance/mentoring, or other government/department programs and directives.

Keywords:
LNF, Literacy Numeracy Fest, FLN Fest, FLN 3.0, EBRC, EBRC guidance, department, government, official, directive, policy, program, "during the fest", "from the fest", "guidance from EBRC", "department training", "official program"

Examples:
- "Through FLN Fest 3.0."
- "Guidance from EBRC and department officials."
- "We implemented this after the department training."
- "Idea came from activities done in the Literacy Numeracy Fest."

**Trainings & Peer Learning**
Definition:
Use this category when the idea came from professional development (trainings, workshops, seminars, webinars) or from peers (colleagues, headmaster) and observing other schools. Exclude references that explicitly tie to LNF/FLN; those belong in Category 1.

Keywords:
training, workshop, seminar, webinar, orientation, DIET, B.Ed, teacher training, course, colleagues, headmaster, peer collaboration, observing other schools, teacher meeting, mentorship (if not EBRC/LNF-specific)

Examples:
- "Through webinar and seminar."
- "Learned this at a workshop."
- "I saw this working in another school and adapted it."
- "Suggested during a teacher meeting."

**Self-Observation & Self-Motivation**
Definition:
Use this category when the idea emerged from the teacher's own observation of students or classroom realities, personal experience, reflective practice, or self-study. This covers ideas that respond to student needs (e.g., low reading skills) noticed by the teacher.

Keywords:
observed students, low reading skills, slow learners, lack of resources, I noticed, I felt, by experience, personal experience, self-study, observing students, student need, classroom observation, realized, noticed

Examples:
- "Low reading skills of the students, so I started reading activities."
- "I saw students were lacking in reading, hence the reading corner."
- "By experience, I thought this would help them."

**Suggested or Supported by Parents or Community**
Definition:
Use this category when the idea originated from parents, guardians, the School Management Committee (SMC), or wider community input. Includes ideas raised or supported during PTMs or community meetings.

Keywords:
parents, parent meeting, PTM, guardians, community, village, SMC, school managing committee, parent suggestion, community meeting, parental involvement

Examples:
- "Through parent-teacher meeting we decided to start homework support."
- "Parents suggested a reading program."
- "Idea came from the SMC discussion."

**Other (Last Resort)**
Definition:
Use this only when the response clearly does not fit Categories 1–4. This includes ideas coming from general external media, vague statements, or unclear sources.

Keywords:
YouTube, social media, external media, random source, not specified, unclear, "just came to mind", banks, army (if unrelated), other

Examples:
- "I saw this on YouTube." (if not part of formal training or self-study)
- "It just came to my mind."
- "Idea came from external non-educational events."

Coding Notes and Rules:
1. If a response explicitly mentions LNF, FLN Fest, FLN 3.0, EBRC, or department program, code it as Category 1.
2. If a response mentions "training", "workshop", "webinar", or "peer observation" but also mentions LNF/EBRC, prefer Category 1 when the LNF/EBRC/program is clearly the source.
3. If the source is the teacher's own observation of student problems (e.g., "low reading skills", "slow learners"), code Category 3.
4. Use Category 4 only when parents/community/SMC are explicitly referenced as the source or supporter.
5. Use Category 5 sparingly — only when the origin is unclear or genuinely outside the other categories.

questions.csv_column: Q3. What did you do to implement this improvement?
questions.question_text: What did you do to implement this improvement?

response_fields.description: One of: Steps Mentioned, No Steps Mentioned, No Response / Short Response / Insufficient Information

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY DEFINITIONS (Choose ONE):

**1. Steps Mentioned**
Definition:
Use this category when the response contains clear, specific, or even partially detailed actions taken by the teacher. 
These may include activities, processes, routines, materials used, interactions, planning, or any step-by-step descriptions.

Keywords / Signals:
I did..., I started..., I taught..., I conducted..., We organised..., I created..., I arranged..., Action words like: formed, implemented, guided, monitored, followed, met, planned, used materials, involved parents, rearranged, set up, practiced.

Examples:
""I created a reading corner and asked students to read daily.""
""I conducted weekly reading sessions.""
""I rearranged the seating for better group learning.""
""I met parents and gave them instructions.""

**2. No Steps Mentioned**
Definition:
Use this when the response is related to the improvement, BUT does NOT describe any action taken by the teacher. 
The answer may talk about goals, hopes, observations, or general statements without describing what they actually did.

Keywords / Signals:
Responses that talk about results, problems, intentions, or general ideas but NO actions.

Examples:
""Students improved a lot.""
""I wanted to make the classroom better.""
""I planned to help them read.""
""I encouraged them."" (when no actual method is described)

**3. No Response / Short Response / Insufficient Information**
Definition:
Use this ONLY when the response is:
- Completely blank
- Extremely short (1–3 words)
- Not meaningful
- Unrelated to steps
- A placeholder response or filler text

Keywords / Signals:
NA, N/A, None, Nothing, -, yes, okay, good, ""by experience"", or any very short fragment that does not explain anything.

Examples:
""NA""
""Nothing""
""Not sure""
""Improved""
""Good""
""Done""
""Already mentioned""
Blank response.

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY DEFINITIONS (USE STRICTLY):

**1. Students (Interest, Participation, Engagement)**
Definition:
Use this category when students’ enthusiasm, cooperation, interest, participation, or motivation helped the teacher implement the improvement.

Keywords:
students' interest, student participation, cooperation, willingness, motivation, curiosity, active involvement, learners supported.

Examples:
""Students were interested in the activities.""
""Children participated actively which helped me continue the improvement.""

**2. Teachers & Staff (Colleague or Peer Support)**
Definition:
Use this category when colleagues, peers, school staff, or the headmaster played a supportive role. This includes teamwork, emotional support, planning help, or sharing materials.

Keywords:
colleagues, teachers supported, teamwork, peer help, cooperation, headmaster support, school staff, collaboration with teachers.

Examples:
""My colleagues helped arrange the classroom.""
""The headmaster encouraged me to take up this improvement.""

**3. Program Support (LNF, EBRC, Resources, Training)**
Definition:
Use this when support came from structured programs, training, or institutional guidance, including:
- Literacy Numeracy Fest (LNF / FLN Fest 3.0)
- EBRC guidance, mentoring, training
- Department-led programs
- Program-provided TLM, materials, resources
- Webinars, seminars, workshops

Keywords:
LNF, Literacy Numeracy Fest, FLN Fest, EBRC, EBRC guidance, department training, workshop, webinar, seminar, materials provided, resources, TLM, program support.

Examples:
""EBRC guidance helped me implement the idea.""
""The LNF training gave me the tools needed to start.""

**4. Self-Motivation (Internal Drive / Personal Commitment)**
Definition:
Use this category when the teacher relies on personal motivation, professional commitment, reflective practice, self-drive, or experience as the main enabling factor.

Keywords:
my motivation, my effort, my interest, personal commitment, I was determined, my experience, internal drive, self-motivated.

Examples:
""My own determination helped me continue the work.""
""My experience guided me in implementing the improvement.""

**5. Parents & Community (External Social Support)**
Definition:
Use this category when parents, guardians, SMC, community members, or village groups supported or encouraged the improvement.

Keywords:
parents, guardians, PTM, parent support, community, village, SMC, community involvement, parental cooperation.

Examples:
""Parents supported by encouraging reading at home.""
""SMC members motivated us to continue.""

**6. School Leadership (Headmaster / Administration Support)**
Definition:
Use this when the teacher received explicit support or encouragement from school leadership such as the headmaster or school administration. 
This category is distinct and separate from general colleague support.

Keywords:
headmaster, HM support, school leader, school administration, leadership guidance, school-level support.

Examples:
""The headmaster guided me throughout the process.""
""School administration provided encouragement.""

**7. Other**
Definition:
Use this category only when the response clearly does not fit any of the above six categories or the source of support is unclear or too generic.

Examples:
""Everything helped.""
""I don't know.""
Unclear or unrelated statements.

questions.csv_column: Q5: In the next 3-6 months, do you plan to do anything more for the improvement you led?
questions.question_text: In the next 3-6 months, do you plan to do anything more for the improvement you led?

response_fields.name: category
response_fields.description: One of: HAS SOME PLAN, CONTINUE / ASPIRATIONAL, NO PLAN

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY DEFINITIONS (Choose ONE):

**HAS SOME PLAN**
Definition:
Use this category when the response describes at least one clear, new, specific, and actionable step the teacher plans to take in the next 3–6 months.
The action must be a concrete initiative the teacher intends to personally implement.

Nagaland-specific indicators:
Organizing PTMs or meetings, creating/expanding reading corners, setting up class libraries, adding books, forming student groups, conducting weekly or Saturday tests, preparing models, planning exhibitions, planting trees, organizing reading day/week, starting new activities inspired by LNF or EBRC, adding new TLM or learning materials, building smart class or infrastructure improvements.

Action keywords:
organize, create, add, build, prepare, conduct, form, start, initiate, implement, arrange, introduce, expand, set up.

Examples:
""I want to organize weekly reading day activities.""
""I will prepare models with students and form groups.""
""We will create a class library and add more books.""
""I am planning to conduct weekly tests.""
""A theme-based PTM will be organized.""
""I will expand the reading program started during the fest.""

**CONTINUE / ASPIRATIONAL**
Definition:
Use this category when the teacher expresses intent, motivation, or general goals but does NOT describe any new specific and actionable step.
This includes responses that indicate continuation, maintenance, effort, or aspiration without detailing what will actually be done.

Nagaland-specific indicators:
Continuing reading activities, maintaining current routines, motivating students, trying to improve student skills, giving best effort, wanting to improve learning levels, general improvement goals without action steps, continuing what they started during LNF.

Keywords:
continue, carry on, keep doing, maintain, sustain, try to do better, motivate, support, improve learning level, work harder, increase participation, give my best, improve attendance.

Examples:
""I will continue the reading activities.""
""I will motivate the students to do better.""
""We will try to improve their reading level.""
""I want to help them become more interested in learning.""
""I will keep supporting slow learners.""

**NO PLAN**
Definition:
Use this category when the response clearly lacks any actionable plan.
This includes explicit non-answers, vague responses, placeholders, very short replies, or plans dependent entirely on external factors outside the teacher's control.

Nagaland-specific indicators:
Blank responses, ""nothing more"", ""not sure"", ""good"", ""continuity"", ""PBL"" used as filler, ""plan not ready"", ""no space in school"", ""depends on higher authority"".

Keywords:
nothing, no plan, not ready, cannot say, don't know, didn't think yet, no idea, depends on, shortage, no space, waiting for department, empty, thank you, good.

Examples:
""Nothing more.""
""Not sure.""
""No plan yet.""
""Depends on higher authority.""
""There is no space in the school to do more.""
""I cannot say anything right now.""

questions.categorization_criteria:
CATEGORY DEFINITIONS:

**Student-Related Issues**
Definition:
Use this category when the challenge is directly related to student behavior, capacity, or participation. This includes difficulty in reading, irregular attendance, poor discipline, low motivation, lack of interest, slow learning pace, or students not cooperating.

Keywords:
attendance, irregular, absent, discipline, misbehavior, low interest, lack of interest, slow learners, reading difficulty, weak students, lack of participation, motivation issues, students not cooperating.

Examples:
- "Students have low reading skills which slows the process."
- "Attendance is irregular."
- "Children lose interest quickly."
- "Discipline issues make it hard to conduct activities."

**Lack of Resources / Infrastructure**
Definition:
Use this when the challenge is due to lack of materials, infrastructure constraints, or absence of physical or learning resources. This includes shortage of books, TLM, space, furniture, classrooms, electricity, or damaged infrastructure.

Keywords:
lack of resources, no TLM, no books, shortage of materials, no space, infrastructure issues, damaged building, no library, lack of furniture, no electricity, insufficient classrooms.

Examples:
- "Lack of books made it difficult to run reading activities."
- "There is no space to set up a reading corner."
- "The school does not have the required materials."

**Time / Workload**
Definition:
Use this category when the teacher mentions lack of time, multiple responsibilities, administrative tasks, too much workload, or being unable to balance teaching and improvement tasks.

Keywords:
no time, workload, too much work, busy schedule, administrative tasks, multitasking, difficult to manage time, many responsibilities, extra duties.

Examples:
- "I have too much workload which reduces time for activities."
- "Administrative duties take most of my time."
- "Managing multi-grade teaching reduces time for improvements."

**Teacher / Staff Issues**
Definition:
Use this when the challenge is related to shortage of teachers, lack of colleague support, uncooperative staff, or dependency on limited manpower. This includes situations where the teacher is handling too many classes or teaching alone.

Keywords:
teacher shortage, no support from teachers, lack of staff, alone, managing multiple classes, no cooperation, limited manpower, only one teacher.

Examples:
- "Teacher shortage makes it hard to continue the improvement."
- "I am the only teacher handling many classes."
- "Colleagues were not available to support the activity."

**Parent & Community Challenges**
Definition:
Use this when challenges arise from parents or the community — such as parents not cooperating, low involvement, not supporting learning at home, or community-related disruptions.

Keywords:
parents not cooperating, low parental involvement, community issues, SMC issues, home environment problems, parents do not support homework, lack of awareness, village-level issues.

Examples:
- "Parents do not support reading practice at home."
- "Community involvement is low."
- "Parents are not serious about attendance."

**Program / Policy Limitations**
Definition:
Use this category when challenges arise due to constraints from programs, administrative expectations, bureaucratic delays, or insufficient departmental support. This includes lack of clarity from official programs, insufficient follow-up from EBRC, or system-level constraints.

Keywords:
department, EBRC not available, program limitations, policy constraints, official delay, waiting for department support, unclear instructions.

Examples:
- "EBRC support was limited."
- "We are waiting for department approval."
- "Program instructions were unclear."

**Other / Unclear**
Definition:
Use this category only when the challenge does not fit any of the above categories OR is too vague or generic to classify meaningfully.

Examples:
- "General challenges."
- "Cannot say."
- "Many issues but not specific."

reading corner, class library, TLM, group work, activity-based, classroom beautification, new teaching methods, subject improvement, reorganize classroom, create materials, improve classroom environment.

Examples:
- "I will set up a reading corner."
- "Plan to use more TLM and group activities."
- "We will reorganize the classroom for better learning."

**Student Learning & Academic Development**
Definition:
Use this category when the planned improvement focuses on student learning outcomes, academic progress, attendance, discipline, or strengthening foundational skills.

Keywords:
improve reading, writing, numeracy, slow learners, attendance, participation, discipline, improve learning outcomes, develop skills, academic support.

Examples:
- "I want to improve the reading levels of all students."
- "We will support slow learners through daily practice."
- "I plan to increase student participation."

**School Environment, Infrastructure & Resources**
Definition:
Use this category when the teacher plans to improve school infrastructure, learning resources, campus environment, or physical facilities.

Keywords:
cleanliness, garden, plantation, library setup, smart class, renovation, furniture, school compound improvement, infrastructure, beautification, creating safe space.

Examples:
- "Planning to start a kitchen garden."
- "Improve the school library with more books."
- "We will beautify the school compound."

**Parent & Community Engagement**
Definition:
Use this category when the teacher plans to involve parents or the community in school activities or student learning.

Keywords:
PTM, parent meeting, community meeting, SMC involvement, awareness program, parents helping with learning, home-learning support, community participation.

Examples:
- "I will organize monthly PTMs."
- "Plan to work with parents to improve attendance."
- "Community will be involved in school activities."

**Teacher Collaboration & Professional Practices**
Definition:
Use this category for plans involving collaboration among teachers, improved planning routines, collective activities, or professional practices.

teacher meetings, collaboration, planning sessions, peer support, monitoring systems, professional development.

Examples:
- "We will hold weekly teacher meetings to plan lessons."
- "More collaboration among teachers is planned."

**Program / Training / Department-Led Activities**
Definition:
Use this category when future plans draw from departmental programs, EBRC guidance, LNF learnings, training insights, or upcoming initiatives from the Education Department.

Keywords:
LNF, FLN Fest, EBRC guidance, department program, applying training, training-based activities, program follow-up.

Examples:
- "We will continue LNF-inspired activities."
- "I will apply what I learned in the training."

**Other**
Definition:
Use this when the response does not fit any of the categories above or is too broad or mixed to classify clearly.

Use this when the response is unclear, irrelevant, too brief, or does not fit any of the above categories.

thank you, good, unclear, general statements, placeholder text, blank responses.

Examples:
